repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: This collection contains original and reproductions of lithographs, engravings, and woodcuts of the Holy Land and Europe, cartographic catalogues, and various resources for cartographic collection. The materials date from 1683-2007. The majority of the lithographs were published in the 1830s and 1840s, while the cartographic catalogues are from the 20th Century. The lithographs were produced by noted artists David Roberts, J.M.W. Turner, and others. In the past, Dr. Samuel Halperin has donated art, maps of the Holy Land, and a collection of bibles to George Washington University. Gift of Samuel Halperin, 2007

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Samuel Halperin collection, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Samuel Halperin, 2007 (Accession 2007.074) with an addition in 2009 (Accession 2009.028)

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Samuel Halperin (May 10, 1930 - May 6, 2014), was a leader in education policy, has repeatedly donated valuable and significant collections to George Washington University. From 1969-1981, he headed leadership training programs at GW. He was awarded The President's Medal of George Washington University, the highest honor awarded by the President of the University. Past recipients include Vaclav Havel, Victor Borge, Walter Cronkite, Abba Eban, and Mikhail Gorbachev.

Dr. Halperin earned his bachelor's and master's degrees in 1952 and his Ph.D. in 1956, all in political science and all at Washington University in St. Louis. He began teaching political science at Wayne State University before winning a Congressional Fellowship from the American Political Science Association. He was in Washington D.C. during President Lyndon Johnson's Great Society and became an avid participant. As assistant U.S. commissioner of education for legislation, and, later, as a deputy assistant secretary of health, education, and welfare, he helped craft the historic church-state compromise that cleared the way for passage of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, providing federal funding for programs to help low-income children in public and private schools. He was also active in the Higher Education Act, which provided substantial new sources of financial aid for college students.

In 1986, Dr. Halperin went to the William T. Grant Foundation as the study director of its Commission on Work, Family, and Citizenship. There, he co-authored two landmark reports, "The Forgotten Half: Non-College Youth in America" and "The Forgotten Half: Pathways to Success for America's Youth and Young Families." In an attempt to enact recommendations from these reports, Dr. Halperin founded the American Youth Policy Forum (AYPF) in 1993. The AYPF brings together various interested parties with the goal of bridging the gap between research, policy, and practice in the fields of education, youth development, and employment readiness.

Dr. Halperin also served as President of the Institute for Educational Leadership, and has written or edited a dozen books on the political process and educational policy. He has taught at American, Duke, and Columbia Universities. In addition to his GW honor and numerous other distinctions, he has received the American Association of Community College's Harry S. Truman Award.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains original and reproductions of lithographs, engravings and woodcuts of the Holy Land and Europe, cartographic catalogues, and various resources for cartographic collection. The materials date from 1486-2007. The majority of the lithographs were published in the 1830s and 1840s, while the cartographic catalogues are from the 20th Century. The lithographs were produced by noted artists David Roberts, J.M.W. Turner, and others.
In the past, Dr. Samuel Halperin has donated art, maps of the Holy Land, and a collection of bibles to George Washington University.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: David Roberts lithographs, Lithographs from the Holy Land and Europe, Cartographic catalogues, and Cartographic collection resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains lithographs produced by David Roberts. Most of the lithographs are hand-colored although a few are the uncolored originals. They are lithographs from various locations in the Holy Land, and are arranged chronologically. Roberts (1796-1864), was a Scottish painter born in Edinburgh, and is known primarily for his detailed prints of Egypt and the Near East produced during the 1840s from sketches made during long tours of the region. This work, and his large oil paintings of similar subjects, made him a prominent Orientalist painter. In 1838, Roberts toured Egypt, Nubia, the Sinai, the Holy Land, Jordan and Lebanon. Throughout, he produced a vast collection of drawings and watercourse sketches. He returned to Edinburgh in 1840 and worked with lithographer Louis Haghe to produce the lavishly illustrated plates of the Sketches in the Holy Land and Syria, and Egypt and Nubia series. Roberts died suddenly in 1864, though after more than 150 years his paintings are still the most beloved and popular illustrations of Egypt and are highly sought after by collectors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is composed primarily of lithographs, woodcuts and engravings of the Holy Land, though there are a few from various European cities. They range in date from 1683-1880, while the bulk was published in the 1830s and 1840s. A handful of the drawings were done by well-known artist J.M.W. Turner, who was a colleague of David Roberts, and published in London. The collection is divided into two sections, one focusing on the Holy Land, the other on Europe. Both sections are organized chronologically, with undated lithographs in the back of each section. Most of the lithographs are matted.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Biblical scene relating the binding of Isaac, surrounded by the verses in Genesis 22, read shortly after the Jewish New Year. The placard may be intended as a wall hanging for a sukkah.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Also known as "Sheviti", placard with color illustrated biblical verses placed on the eastern wall of the prayer room above the prayer leader's lectern.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Illustrations by David Wander, calligraphy and micrography by Yonah Weinreb. This leaf contains the text of the passage beginning Ve-hi she-amdah. The illustration below shows pyramids in the background and what appear to be modern industrial crematoria in the foreground.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Jerusalem: A.L. Monzon lithographic press, n.d. (late 19th-early 20th century). Hebrew and German seal of the College on bottom left. The names of the College's administrators, Rabbi Sorach Epstein and Rabbi Simcha Winograd, are given in an English address at the bottom.

did.unittitle: Illustrations by David Wander, calligraphy and micrography by Yonah Weinreb. This leaf contains the concluding paragraph of the Haggadah text, with the words Le-shanah ha-ba'ah bi Yrushalayim in large colored letters below.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material of this series is a collection of cartographic catalogues from around the world. Most of the catalogues are undated, including some from 2007. These catalogues list the collection of maps offered by various dealers. The largest collection of catalogues comes from Francis Edwards, Jonathan Potter, and Richard Arkway, Inc. There are a few catalogues in foreign languages, notably German and Italian. This series is arranged alphabetically in document boxes, with map dealers arranged by their first names (i.e., Jonathan Potter Gallery is listed under "J" rather than "P").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series, entitled "Cartographic collection resources," has materials that include brochures, tourist maps, and guides to collectors. Most of the documents are undated. The series is comprised of brochures and buying guides for cartographic collectors. There are also a few pamphlets containing articles dealing with matters in this field, tourist maps for visitors to the Holy Land, and guides for visitors to the Holy Land, primarily dealing with the collection and study of antique maps.

did.unittitle: Materials related to maps of Israel
Survey of Israel road map [shows armistice lines and demilitarized zones]
Peel Royal Commission on Partition of Palestine [19 maps]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series, entitled "Magazines and posters," has issues of the periodical Map Collector. Issues range from the magazine's debut in 1977 until 1993. There is also one issue of Mercator's World, a similar publication, from September/October 1999. This periodical focuses on the world of map collecting, featuring articles, buying guides, and other useful information for collectors. There are also three posters for Washington, D.C. historical organizations.

did.unittitle: Jerusalem From the Mount of Olives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains has various pamphlets, articles, and other forms of propaganda of an Anti-semitic nature, created between 1946 and 1970.
